results.title: War of the colossal beast
results.creator_credit: Bert I. Gordon and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “The Amazing colossal man” (Bert I. Gordon, 1957), the gigantic beast of the original is feared to have survived his almighty fall, and now quite deranged, to be posing an even greater threat. Incoherent and hideously disfigured, the monster is located in Mexico, but after thwarting the authorities attempts to tame him, goes on the rampage. Director and effects maestro Bert I. Gordon specialised in B-Grade 1950s horror, and does not disappoint here, even adding extra dazzle to the finale which is presented in colour.

results.title: Suddenly [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lewis Allen, Robert Bassler and Libra Productions
results.brief_description: Set in a sleepy US town by the name of “Suddenly”, an attractive war widow and mother of young son “Pidge” is pursued by the local sheriff Todd Shaw (Sterling Hayden) with romance in mind. Todd gets word that the President of the United States is to make an impromptu visit to the town and the FBI arrive to set up a secure perimeter around the railway station. Overlooking the station is the home of the widow Ellen (Nancy Gates) and her father-in-law (James Gleason), an ex-secret service agent. The film becomes a hostage drama as three gangsters lead by John Barron (Frank Sinatra) attempt to assassinate the president with a rifle from the house on the hill. The film provides a commentary on the role of the hand-gun in a post-world war America. Because of the similarity of the plot to real life, the film was withdrawn from general distribution after the assassination of JFK. Part of a two-disc set, with one disc being an Audio CD. Also contains a booklet with information and photos of Frank Sinatra.

results.title: The Brain eaters
results.creator_credit: Bruno VeSota, Edwin Nelson and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: Crawling, slimy things terror-bent on destroying the world! So runs the tagline for “The Brain eaters”, classic B-grade science fiction about a mysterious alien structure found jutting out of the earth, in small-town USA. After some studious investigating, a senator and a doctor discover that aliens have infiltrated and are controlling the townsfolk. The terror of a mind-controlling alien threat and subsequent loss of governmental power operates as an analogy for the fear of Communist invasion and the accusations of brainwashing that were likened to the “Red threat”.

results.title: The Shaggy dog
results.creator_credit: Charles Barton, Bill Walsh, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Family comedy film around the theme of fantasy and magic. The discovery of a magic ring changed young Wilby Daniels’ (Tommy Kirk) life forever. Suddenly he could transform himself into a large sheepdog - but the problem was he had no control as to when this was going to happen. Wilby did not need this in his life right now, just when he had his eye on the rather pretty Allison (Annette Funicello). He had to break the spell and the only way to do that was by performing some virtuous deed. Cast also includes Fred MacMurray, Jean Hagen, Tim Considine.

results.title: The Shaggy D.A.
results.creator_credit: Robert Stevenson, Bill Anderson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Sequel to Disney’s “The Shaggy Dog” (released 17 years earlier), this family comedy is full of slapstick moments and a plot that takes you from the world of reality to the fantastic and bizarre. Dean Jones stars as the now grown-up Wilby Daniels, who is campaigning to become a district attorney and Keenan Wynn plays his villainous arch-rival, John Slade. The campaign is turned on its head when Daniels is transformed into a sheepdog and Slade into a disgruntled bulldog and it becomes a contest between the two canines. Cast also includes Tim Conway, Suzanne Pleshette, Jo Ann Worley.

results.title: The Computer wore tennis shoes
results.creator_credit: Robert Butler, Bill Anderson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Featuring a very young Kurt Russell as Dexter, student leader at Medfield College who is transformed into a human being with a hard drive memory when the computer he is repairing is unexpectedly struck by a bolt of lightning. This act of nature presents all manner of problems for Dexter as his brain begins to discover certain information about the somewhat suspect activities of the College’s rich benefactor A.J. Arno (Cesar Romero) who donated the computer in the first place. The story bounces along from adventure to adventure, revealing secrets and plans, a kidnapping and a rescue. Cast includes Joe Flynn, William Schallert, Alan Hewitt.

results.title: Camille 2000
results.creator_credit: Radley Metzger, Spear Productions and Audubon Films
results.brief_description: The swinging sixties are reflected in this free-love erotica romance produced and directed by Radley Metzger. Portrayed via highly stylised costume and set design, the hedonistic lifestyle indulged by Marguerite (Daniele Gaubert) and her friends is in the realm of fantasy. How the very wealthy (or proteges of the wealthy such as Marguerite) spend their time - with wild parties, drugs and alcohol fuelling their passions. The swarthy Armand (Nino Castenuovo) arrives in Rome and instantly falls for Marguerite, upsetting the ‘live for now’ approach she has to love. They begin an affair that sees them run away to live on a yacht until Armand’s father intervenes trying to save his son’s money and reputation. Marguerite returns to her old ways and ends up relying more on drugs to get her through the pain of loosing her true love. They see each other again at a kinky ‘prison’ themed sex party and Camille ends up in hospital where the lovers are able to re-unite. The ‘2000’ of the title not a reference to a year but to the number of lovers Armand would have to have before he could forget Marguerite! Based on the novel “The Lady of the Camilias” by Alexandre Dumas. Shot in Rome with music by Piero Piccioni. Cast includes Elenora Rossi, Robert Bisacco.

results.title: The Lickerish quartet
results.brief_description: This erotic fantasy film is set in an ancient Italian castle where a man and woman live with her adult son. Opening with the family viewing a pornographic movie and commenting on it, the trio then venture out to the local carnival where they meet the star of the movie now working as a motorcycle stuntwoman. They invite the woman back to the house to have a ‘party’ and watch the film together. Bizarrely she is no longer in the film and has been replaced. One by one the mysterious blonde seduces each of the family members resulting a sexual awakening for all of them, until in the end, physical reality is lost to them and they too become part of movie for others to watch. Highly stylised sets, costumes and funky music add to the swinging sixties feel of this Radley Metzger fantasy romp. Based on the story “Hide and Seek” by Michael De Forrest and Radley Metzger. Cast includes Silvana Venturelli, Frank Wolff, Erika Remberg, Paolo Turco.

results.title: The City of the dead = Horror hotel
results.creator_credit: John Moxey, Donald Taylor and Vulcan Film (UK)
results.brief_description: A young college student, intrigued by the historical practices of witchcraft conducted in the 17th century, travels to a small town for further investigation. There she meets a mysterious end, leaving her brother and boyfriend to uncover the truth about the town’s malevolent inhabitants. Filmed in black and white, and released the same year as Hitchcock’s “Psycho”, this horror tale is suitably menacing, relying very little on special effects, but more on atmosphere and a chilling narrative. Also known as “Horror hotel”.

results.title: The House that dripped blood
results.creator_credit: Peter Duffell, Milton Subotsky, Max J Rosenberg, Cinerama and Amicus Productions
results.brief_description: Four short stories are linked by a police investigation into the dire circumstances in which occupants of a haunted house perish. A mystery writer inhabits the house in order to finish his latest novel, but is overtaken by the idea that his fictionalised killer really exists. In the second episode, a retired businessman becomes obsessed with a waxwork figure of a beautiful woman. Thirdly, a single father to a young girl, who keeps her mysteriously separated from society, falls victim to witchcraft. In the final episode a horror-film actor, seeking authenticity in his work, is given the cloak of a real vampire. These stories are wonderfully creepy and rely not so much on bloodshed, as on supernatural thrills and gruesome trajectories.
